title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
The ‚Äú90/10‚Äù rule

90% of the work you do will occupy only 10% of your presentation time/space.


Students tend to make reports and dashboards using the timeline they experienced in the analysis
Instead, focus on conclusions and takeaways
Differentiate between communicating results and documenting a process (both are important!)

title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
The ‚Äú90/10‚Äù rule
10%:

Data cleaning and wrangling details
Assumption checking for models or statistical tests
Combined results all in one visual

90%:

Specific conclusions from tests - ‚Äúwe found evidence that‚Ä¶‚Äù
Plots of model predictions and summary statistics
Visuals highlighting individual takeaways - ‚ÄúCalifornia has higher predicted prices than the Midwest‚Äù

title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
The ‚ÄúNewspaper Headline‚Äù approach

For each analysis, what is the headline a newspaper would use.


NO: Statements of general accomplishment - ‚ÄúWe fit a model to predict prices of fast food items.‚Äù
NO: Model assessment - ‚ÄúOur model has 93% accuracy on a test set.‚Äù
NO: Results in technical form - ‚ÄúThe variable found to be most significant was location of store.‚Äù
NO: Unspecific results - ‚ÄúLocation of fast food store impacts price.‚Äù
YES: Results of public interest in plain terms with specific knowledge: ‚ÄúFast food prices are 50% higher in California than in the Midwest.‚Äù

title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
Dashboards as ‚ÄúQ&A‚Äù

The goal of an interactive dashboard is to replace you, by giving the audience a way to ask and answer questions themselves.


Anticipate follow up questions to the main ‚Äúheadlines‚Äù.
Go from general to specific - e.g.¬†‚ÄúHere is a plot of the average price of burgers over time. Use this drop-down to filter by state.‚Äù
Keep your dashboard sanitized against bad statistical choices - e.g., don‚Äôt allow users to select ‚ÄúShow logistic regression‚Äù for numeric data.

title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
‚ÄúWhy should I care?‚Äù

Dashboards and presentations are for your target audience, not your peers.


What is interesting to a data scientist might not be interesting to your target audience.
Use personas:

Give your client a name
Why does this client want your analysis?
What is their specific stake in the data?
What level of technical content will they understand and appreciate?

Stay focused on how the client will use the analysis to make decisions.

title: Communicating Statistical Results
text:
Example

My client is Nisha, a CEO of a small restaurant chain that competes with local fast food. She has a degree in business administration, so she understands basic statistics. She has hired me to analyze price trends in the food industry.


Nisha is a CEO of a small business - she is probably interested in how to keep her restaurant solvent
We can quote basic statistics, but we should not go deep into modeling math.
She has asked specifically about prices, so our presentation should focus on that.
She has asked about trends, so our ‚Äúnewspaper headline‚Äù should be about changes over time.
We should state how our analysis will help her set her prices at her restaurants.

title: Workshop Installs & Set-up
text:
Learning Objectives

Manage, process, and load data from non-tabular and non-local sources.
Clean and prepare messy and unstructured data, including handling missing values, and the use of regular expressions to extract information from text data.
Use joins to combine multiple datasets with many-to-many relationships.
Use complex data wrangling pipelines, including multiple pivots and/or multiple grouping levels, to wrangle data.

title: Workshop Installs & Set-up
text:
Unit A Project
Students will produce a stylized, publication-ready report that performs exploratory data analysis to address specific research questions.
Data for the report will be taken from multiple online and non-csv sources, and will require the use of regular expressions to collect, clean, or wrangle their data.
Research questions will be provided that require complex, multi-step data wrangling, and results should be communicated using complex and polished visualizations.

'sampleSize': the name of the object that stores the value (to be used later in other code chunks)
